options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overview of objective and subjective theories in deviance, sociological analysis of the Great and Little Tradition, theories on the self, along with virtual and actual identities.

Reviewing and analyzing notable sociological works on race, social group dynamics, and institutionally proliferated social issues. Solid foundational background knowledge on the roots of contemporary race issues, how we developed our sociological normalcies in America and how we and if we can truly define deviant behavior as it is relative to social norms, and what we can do to view and treat our analysis of social interactions in a manner which can promote social equality but still be critical!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Anderson is a legend. Take this class to hear his perspective on the world and the way people interact with each other in day to day life, especially in the context of race. The class does get pretty repetitive as Professor Anderson has a set of beliefs that he connects to all the class material. This could be a strength or weakness, depending on your stomach for hearing similar things over and over again.
Having Elijah Anderson as our professor is really cool and he is fun to listen to but I feel like his demeanor would have a more impactful magnitude in person.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It all up to the student how well they engage in the course as the format allows for students to slack if they want. However, I think all the students were engaged and willing to share ideas!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Take this class for Professor Anderson

Hell yes, if you are a sociology student, this is a great course to take in tandem with Sociological Imagination! The combo really equips students with strong academic theories to explore the world of sociology and how we participate in the ever-evolving modernity!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
